data.title: [perceval] Update license and copyright information
data.body:
This PR updates license information for every source code file in Perceval.

I tried updating this using the tool, [vchrombie/grimoirelab-scripts](https://github.com/vchrombie/grimoirelab-scripts).

data.title: Gather data from Pagure
data.body: https://pagure.io/ is an open source issue tracker with Git integration, PRs, stats and other features. Would be nice to extract my own data from it for tracking activity.

organizations.description: NLP/Computational linguistics in Belarus
Shaving yaks so you can shave yaks while you shave yaks.
Kow Tham Monastery and Insight Meditation Center

comments_data.body:
hi @abitrolly, thank you for your interest in this project! I like your proposal!
would you like to try to implement the backend? it could be a nice first contribution :)

In depends. :) I want to extract my daily trail. Perceval seem to dump all available data, which may put too much load on some systems if run daily. Is there a tool that can only follow myself? To track my first contribution. )

organizations.description: NLP/Computational linguistics in Belarus
Shaving yaks so you can shave yaks while you shave yaks.
Kow Tham Monastery and Insight Meditation Center

comments_data.body:
Grimoirelab platform allows to monitor your daily contribution (and much more). For instance, if you have a look to [this Git dashboard](https://opnfv.biterg.io/app/kibana#/dashboard/Git?_g=()) from one of our clients and click on any of the authors, you will see that the visualizations will show just the contributions of that author. If this solution doesn't fit with your needs, you can make a script to daily execute Perceval on the pagure.io repositories you contribute to (and then filter the data you are interested in).
In both cases, you can count on me for both questions about how to proceed or help in coding :)

Note that Perceval can be used in incremental mode (e.g., extracting issues modified after a given date), thus it should not imply too much load on the pagure.io API.
I'd like to pitch in :)

Greetings!
I'd be interested to try to implement Pagure's backend if possible :)
As I understand I will be using the abstract class for backends available, correct?

Great, thank you @propol !
Yes, you can have a look at the other [backends](https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/tree/master/perceval/backends) to see some examples. Feel free to open a PR, and we can iterate over it.

Sure, will do when I have some code to show for it :) 
Thank you
I would like to work on this

organizations.description: Open Food Facts is a collaborative, free and open database of food products from around the world.

comments_data.body:
that's great, @PrajwalM2212 ! 

Please have a look at https://github.com/inishchith/chaoss-microtasks/tree/master/microtask-1 and https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-sirmordred#setting-up-a-pycharm-dev-environment to set up a dev environment.

The backend could receive as input the project name and return its issue. We have already some backends implementing a similar approach for other platforms, for instance:
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/github.py
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/gitlab.py
- https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/perceval/backends/core/jira.py

Feel free to have a look at them,
Thanks

Hi!! @valeriocos As no updates have been there on this issue for a while can I work on it.  Also, can you help me understand how the `CATEGORIES` are decided for a particular backend??
Thank you

Hi @animeshk08 , thank you for your interest in this issue. 

It would be great if you can work on this issue. As references, you can rely on the gitlab and github backends. Feel free to open a pull request linked to this issue, so we can help you with the implementation.

Categories are the types of the data we can extract from a backend. They are generally defined based on some business needs/scenarios. For instance, if we focus on the data we can extract from a Git repository, possible categories could be commits, branches and tags. Commit is the current and only category available for the Git backend. We implemented it because we needed to calculate commit-based metrics (e.g., number of commits per author, weekday when a commit was created). ATM we don't have any scenario targeting git branches or tags, thus we don't need any of other category for Git.

Another example is the data we extract from Gitlab. In this case, our need was to define metrics around issues and merge requests, thus we created 2 categories in the Gitlab backend to fetch these infos.

WRT the backend for Pagure, we can start by fetching the issues for a given project. Other data available through the API can be the target of future backend improvements.

Let me know if you have any doubts, thanks.
Thank you @valeriocos for the detailed clarification.

Hi!! @valeriocos . I am successfully able to retrieve issues through perceval for pagure backend. However, I do have some doubts.  I am going to list them here:
1. The issue response for `Pagure` is very similar to`Github` . However, Github backend has `TARGET_ISSUE_FIELDS = ['user', 'assignee', 'assignees', 'comments', 'reactions']` . Now in Github the 'comments' key in the `issue` JSON object returns the number of comments. Hence, there is separate key created names `cooments_data` which is valid. However, via Pagure the `comments` key contains a detailed object as shown below
```
"comments": [
            {
                "comment": "**Metadata Update from @animeshk08**:\n- Issue assigned to animeshk08",
                "date_created": "1583059075",
                "edited_on": null,
                "editor": null,
                "id": 629628,
                "notification": true,
                "parent": null,
                "reactions": {},
                "user": {
                    "fullname": "Animesh Kumar",
                    "name": "animeshk08"
                }
            },
            {
                "comment": "**Metadata Update from @animeshk08**:\n- Issue assigned to animeshk0806 (was: animeshk08)",
                "date_created": "1583157002",
                "edited_on": null,
                "editor": null,
                "id": 629742,
                "notification": true,
                "parent": null,
                "reactions": {},
                "user": {
                    "fullname": "Animesh Kumar",
                    "name": "animeshk08"
                }
            },
            {
                "comment": "Hi this is a new comment\r\n",
                "date_created": "1583157030",
                "edited_on": null,
                "editor": null,
                "id": 629743,
                "notification": false,
                "parent": null,
                "reactions": {
                    "Thumbs up": [
                        "animeshk0806"
                    ]
                },
                "user": {
                    "fullname": "Animesh Kumar",
                    "name": "animeshk08"
                }
            },
            {
                "comment": "> Hi this is a new comment\r\nThis is sample reply",
                "date_created": "1583157261",
                "edited_on": null,
                "editor": null,
                "id": 629745,
                "notification": false,
                "parent": null,
                "reactions": {},
                "user": {
                    "fullname": "Animesh Kumar Singh",
                    "name": "animeshk0806"
                }
            }
        ]
```

As you can see both comment data and reactions are included in this object.
Should I still include separate `comment_data` and `reaction` keys in the `issue` JSON object?
 Do they have direct dependencies anywhere in the future components of grimoirelab?
```
NOTE: There are no sperate API calls to retrieve reactions.
```

2. Some repositories have disabled their issue tracker. In that case, the API response is returned as 404. How should I handle such cases? NOTE: I checked the same for GitHub as well it does not return a 404 response but rather just an empty response. Hence Githu backend does not require such error handling

Thank you for all the help.

Great @animeshk08 !

> 1. The issue ...

Are the comments returned by the Pagure API for a given issue paginated (i.e., only the first X are returned and we need to iterate on the different pages)? If this is the case, it makes sense to have the comments in a different attribute (comments_data), since the backend/client will have some code to fetch the whole set of comments.

Reactions and comments_data don't have a prori direct deps with other components. However the connectors in ELK will be written based on the strucute of the documents returned by Perceval.

> 2. Some repositories ...

If an API endpoint contains the info about the issue tracker enable/disable, the backend could query this endpoint at the very beginning and return an ad-hoc warning message if needed. Another option is to handle this exception when fetching issues. 

Tomorrow I can have a look at the Pagure API and give you a more detailed feedback.

Thank you for the fast reply @valeriocos . 
>Are the comments returned by the Pagure API for a given issue paginated

To the best of my understanding the comments are not paginated. However, a given comment object is returned as below
```
{
                "comment": "This is comment 21",
                "date_created": "1583167920",
                "edited_on": null,
                "editor": null,
                "id": 629814,
                "notification": false,
                "parent": null,
                "reactions": {},
                "user": {
                    "fullname": "Animesh Kumar",
                    "name": "animeshk08"
                }
            }
```
As you can see there is no `user_data` key present in this object. So it still may be considered to either edit the same `comment` key or create a `comment_data` key to accommodate `user_data` in it; if that level of depth is needed. Whichever, implementation do you think is best.
>If an API endpoint contains the info about the issue tracker enable/disable

To the best of my understanding there no API lets us know about this information. Hence we should go for the latter approach.

Please have a look at the following Pagure API documentation and correct me if I am wrong [here](https://pagure.io/api/0/)

Yes, you are right @animeshk08! The pagination seems to exist only for issues.

> As you can see there is no user_data key present in this object. So it still may be considered to either edit the same comment key or create a comment_data key to accommodate user_data in it; if that level of depth is needed. Whichever, implementation do you think is best.

I would not add any `*_data` attribute, since the user information is already included in the comment. Generally the attributes `*_data` contain data extracted from a specific endpoint. For instance, if we focus on GitHub, the comments_data: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/fe3b3a3632177b7b61fb382cd8f0ab8e8c50b7f4/perceval/backends/core/github.py#L380 relies on:
- the comments endpoint: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/fe3b3a3632177b7b61fb382cd8f0ab8e8c50b7f4/perceval/backends/core/github.py#L651)
- the user endpoint: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/fe3b3a3632177b7b61fb382cd8f0ab8e8c50b7f4/perceval/backends/core/github.py#L529

> To the best of my understanding there no API lets us know about this information. Hence we should go for the latter approach.

Perfect (I didn't find any info in the API either)!

data.title: [backend]Added support for Pagure backend
data.body:
This PR address issue #416.
This commit adds support for the pagure
backend to perceval

Signed-off-by: animesh <animuz111@gmail.com>

comments_data.body:
Hi!! @valeriocos. I have added all the changes based on our discussion. Can you please review the code as well as the output response.

Some of the repositories you can look at for performing manual checking are below:
* https://pagure.io/Fedora-Infra/ansible (does not have an issue tracker)
* https://pagure.io/Project-textbase
* https://pagure.io/fedora-qa/blockerbugs

I will work on including unit tests now. Thank you for all the help :)
Thanks for the PR @animeshk08 , I'll have a look at it today

Hi, @valeriocos thank you so much for the reviews. I had made some assumptions in terms of a few arguments. Sorry about that, I will try to send better PR's in the future :)

All the changes are valid, I just had some doubt and I have mentioned it in the review. Please clarify it and I will send an updated PR by today.
Thank you.
Great, thank you @animeshk08 for the quick reply. I've just answered your question.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/29207757/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/29207757)

Coverage increased (+0.05%) to 97.663% when pulling **70a89aa1dccc5152ed4a52cb4c5e4e327ba3595a on animeshk08:pagure-backend** into **d273525c6609ab9bcb8f06a2cb0d78b4c70fa11c on chaoss:master**.

organizations.description: DELIVER BETTER CODE

comments_data.body:
Hi, @valeriocos Really sorry for the delay since the response was updated I had to make some updates in the unit tests. I have made the changes requested by you. Also, I have added the required unit tests for Pagure.

Can you please review the changes :) Thank you so much.
Sorry for the multiple force push. The Coveralls test was not passing for me. It's fixed now :)

Hi, @valeriocos I have made all the changes requested. While reviewing the PR I found one of my data files had wrong data. Sorry about that ;) Can you please review the files. Thanks a lot.

PS: Do you want me to squash all the commits in this PR or just the future ones. Sorry I had a doubt hence did not do it.

Great, thank you @animeshk08 ! Before reviewing the PR, could you include in it also:
- a new entry in the usage doc: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval#usage
- a new entry in the usage help: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval/blob/master/bin/perceval#L34
- an example of use of the pagure backend at https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-perceval#examples

The PR should have just one commit (please follow the guidelines at https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#accepting-contributions to write a commit message and description).
Done! @valeriocos :)
Hi, @valeriocos I have made all the changes. Please have a review. Thank for investing so much time in helping me :)

>Let me know if you are interested in extending ELK to store and process the data coming from pagure repositories :)

I was just going to ask you about it. I am very interested in doing the extension of pagure with ELK :)
I will start it once this PR is completed.

> I was just going to ask you about it. I am very interested in doing the extension of pagure with ELK :)
I will start it once this PR is completed.

You can have a look at the raw connector of gitlab: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/raw/gitlab.py

Done!! @valeriocos 

> You're welcome and sorry for the different iterations on the PR. Just two small changes and that's it :)

I need to improve my documentation skills. Next time there will be much lesser iterations :)

>You can have a look at the raw connector of gitlab: https://github.com/chaoss/grimoirelab-elk/blob/master/grimoire_elk/raw/gitlab.py

Thank you for the reference :)
